Snippet.Text: La Cour!
Please be seated.
I declare open the public hearing on the merits in the case of Georgia against Russia. The case was lodged with the court by the government of Georgia
on the 26th of March 2007 under Article 33 of the Convention. The application was allocated to the fifth
section of the court pursuant to Rule 51, paragraph 3 of the Rules of Court.
The application was declared admissible on the 30th of June 2009.
On the 15th of December 2009 the chamber decided to relinquish jurisdiction in favor of the Grand Chamber, none of the parties having objected to the relinquishment.
From the 31st of January to the 4th of February 2011 a delegation of judges took oral evidence from several witnesses in Strasbourg.
The government of the Russian Federation are represented by their representative Mr. Georgy Matyushkin,
assisted by Ms. Natalia Zyabkina,
first deputy head of the representative's office, as well as by Ms. Zemskova,
Ms. Irina Sergeievna, Mr. Yuri Petukhov,
Ms. Khokhrina, Mr. Spirin,
Ms. Tsimbalova, and Mr. hipitsyn,
advisors.
The government of Georgia are represented by Ms. Tina Burjaliani,
first deputy minister of justice, and by Mr. Levan Meskhoradze,
an agent assisted by Ms. Ketevan Sokmolidze,
Ms. Miriam Vashakidze,
and Ms. Nino Abramishvili, advisors.
I welcome the representatives of the parties in the name of the court.
Having consulted the representatives of the parties, I have determined the order of address is as follows.
Ms. Burjaliani for the government of Georgia will speak first,
and then Mr. Matyushkin for the government of the Russian Federation.
I call Ms. Burjaliani, please.
Good morning, Mr. President, distinguished members of the Court.
As always, it is a great pleasure for me to appear before the European Court of Human Rights on behalf of the Government of Georgia.
I with my co-agents will present Georgia's arguments both on admissibility and the merits of the present case.
Your Excellencies, Though voluminous, the present case is simple.
It is about mass human rights violations exercised by the Respondent State through arrest, detention, and expulsion of ethnic Georgians from the Russian Federation in the fall of 2006.

International community and the Russian human rights defenders, including the Human Rights Commissioner, have qualified the situation as ethnically motivated, gross human rights violations supported and tolerated by the authorities of the Respondent State.
In the words of the Human Rights Watch, ethnic Georgians were singled out.
Thousands of Georgians were detained and expelled, including many Georgians residing legally in Russia.

Human Rights Watch continues, and I quote, Georgian authorities denied basic rights to many of the detained, including access to a lawyer or possibility of appealing the expulsion decisions taken against them.
Most were given trials lasting only a few minutes.
Georgians were held in sometimes appalling conditions of detention, and in some cases were subjected to threats and other ill-treatment.
End of the quote.

The Commissioner for Human Rights of the Russian Federation confirms that in 2006, nationalistic and xenophobic attitudes continued to proliferate in Russia, and that the cases of violence and mass conflicts due to racial, ethnic, or religious intolerance have become quite frequent.
In the course of this litigation, Georgia has furnished the court with a variety of evidence supporting its claims.
The most recent expression of Georgia's observations is provided in the submission of November 30, 2011.

Being conscious of time and the fact that the Honorable Court has access to our more detailed written observations, as well as the first-handed information provided by the witnesses during the hearings of January 30, February 4, 2011, I will elaborate on the most important questions of the case.

In the first part of my presentation, I will show that the facts challenged shall be qualified as administrative practice that makes the rule of exhaustion of domestic remedies inapplicable, as confirmed by the court in its admissibility decision on the present case dated June 30, 2009.
Then I will show that in any case, no effective remedies were available for Georgian nationals in the respondent state at the material time.
In the next part of my presentation, I will summarize Georgia's claims on merits, and finally, I will present the applicant state's prayers for relief.

The facts challenged in Georgia's application constitute administrative practice that automatically relieves the applicant state from the obligation to exhaust domestic remedies before seizing the court.
According to the court's case law, administrative practice comprises two elements, repetition of acts and official tolerance.
In the Ireland v. UK, the repetition of acts has been defined as an accumulation of identical
or analogous breaches which are sufficiently numerous and interconnected to amount not merely to isolated incidents or exceptions, but to a pattern or a system.
Its essential feature is that the acts complained of form a pattern or system in a sense that some link or connection exists in the circumstances surrounding the particular acts.
For example, time and place where the acts occur and the attitude of the persons involved, and that they are not simply a number of isolated acts.
According to the findings in the Greek case, practice arises when there are a substantial number of acts which are the expression of a general situation.

In the same Greek case, it was established that the second element of administrative practice, official tolerance, may be found to exist on two alternative levels, that of the direct superiors of those immediately responsible for the acts involved or that of a higher authority.

Official tolerance exists where, though acts are plainly illegal, they are tolerated in the sense that the superiors of those immediately responsible, though cognizant of such acts, take no action to punish them or prevent their repetition.

Or that higher authority, in face of numerous allegations, manifests indifference by refusing adequate investigation of their truth or falsity, or that in judicial proceedings, a fair hearing of such complaints is denied.
In the Ireland v. UK, the Commission had regard to two factors which must be considered in

relation to each other, namely, knowledge on the part of the superior officers of those having committed the acts in question, or knowledge of higher level authorities and action taken which might have prevented occurrence and repetition of such acts, including punitive and disciplinary action.
In the same case, the Court observed that it is inconceivable that the higher authorities of a State should be, or at least should be, entitled to be unaware of the existence of such practice.
Furthermore, under the Convention, those authorities are strictly liable for the conduct of their subordinates.
They are under duty to impose their will on subordinates and cannot shelter behind their inability to ensure that it is respected.

Practice at the higher level may be found to exist even if the higher authorities have taken certain measures, including criminal prosecution of some of the acts, so long as these measures are not on a scale which is sufficient to put an end to the repetition of acts or to interrupt the pattern or system.
Moreover, in the France, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, and the Netherlands v. Turkey case,
it was noted that an administrative practice may exist in the absence of, or even contrary to, specific legislation.
Mr. President, Your Excellencies, I have briefly overviewed the principles and rules developed
in your case law.
These principles and rules are perfectly applicable to the present case.
Within a short period of time, a few thousand Georgians were singled out by the Respondent State authorities in Moscow, St. Petersburg, and other big Russian cities, and were deported
at least by four chartered flights.
First time ever.

According to the statistics of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Border Police of Georgia, number of deportees from the Russian Federation increased more than eight times in October and November 2006, compared to the previous months and years.
Though extremely instructive, the data collected by the Border Police refer only to those deportees who arrived to Georgia directly from the Russian Federation.
Big number of deportees came through neighboring countries, and their first post of departure is normally not indicated in the entry application.
Thus, a number of deportees should be much higher.
The Respondent State failed to provide any relevant data that could have shed more light on the issue.
Therefore, the applicant submits that the data available in the Ministry of Internal Affairs Border Police of Georgia should be used by the court as a reliable source of information.
As regards the official tolerance, we would like first to kindly draw the court's attention to the official instructions and orders issued by various authorities of the Respondent State.
The instructions issued by local police units in St. Petersburg and in Moscow on October
2 and 3 are implementing the circular number 0215 of September 30, 2006, issued by the Main Directorate of Internal Affairs of St. Petersburg, and circular number 849, issued
a day earlier, September 29, 2006, by the Ministry of Interior of the Russian Federation.
At the same time, the letters demanding information about Georgian pupils and their parents were sent to schools in different parts of the Respondent State.
Many of these pupils and parents were later arrested and deported.
The picture is clear.

On September 29, 2006, the Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs, being politically motivated, issued the order and the subordinated authorities followed by implementing instructions and by the actions.
The Respondent State and its witnesses could not deny that the circulars number 0215 and 849 do exist and that they are ethnic-specific.
They could not deny either that the letters were sent to schools in violation of both domestic and international law.
What the Respondent State denies is that the circulars breach the rights of ethnic Georgians.
In relation to the letters sent to schools, the Respondent State shifts the burden on lower-level local officials.
Unfortunately, despite the repeated attempts and requests from the Court, the Respondent State has not submitted the circular number 0215 and the order number 849 to the Court for its examination.

In light of the disregard of the Court's request, the applicant submits that the Court should draw inferences and make conclusions based on the information available in other sources, including the witness statements, the reports of international and local NGOs, and the report of the Human Rights Commissioner of the Russian Federation.
It is instructive that the Commissioner Lukin officially requested the Prosecutor General of the Russian Federation to investigate the issue of illegal instructions and orders.
We have learned from the Respondent State in the course of this litigation that no conclusive decision was made in this regard.
It is further disappointing that, despite the invitation, we did not have an opportunity to hear Commissioner Lukin and Mr. Piotrowski of St. Petersburg, whose name appears on one
of the important instructions.
Mr. President, Your Excellencies,

In light of the ethnic-specific orders and circulars issued by the Respondent State authorities on September 29 and 30, the identical letters sent to schools in different geographically remote areas, the mass arrest of ethnic Georgians, and very light or no punishment of those low-level officials whose responsibilities could not have been denied, it would be inconceivable to argue that the anti-Georgian campaign was a local initiative of overzealous officials.
In fact, it is obvious that the Respondent State orchestrated the illegal policy of arrest, detention in human conditions, and expulsion of ethnic Georgians.

The absence of adequate investigation and punishment supports that the campaign was orchestrated by the high authorities of the Respondent State and those officials whose letters and teletypes leaked in the media were just implementing the superior orders.

Therefore the Applicant State submits that the Court shall establish administrative practice in the present case and shall find a breach of Article 38 by the Respondent State for non-cooperation and non-disclosure of the requested documents.
Mr. President, Your Excellencies, in line with your own findings in previous case law,
including the admissibility decision on the present case, we further submit that the administrative practice makes the rule of exhaustion of domestic remedies inapplicable.

In alternative, should the Court rule otherwise, we would like to submit that the rule of exhaustion of domestic remedies does not apply to the present case, as there were no effective remedies available to ethnic Georgians in the Russian Federation, at least in the period before seizing the Court.
The Applicant State provided very detailed arguments on exhaustion of domestic remedies in its written observations.
In particular, I would kindly draw the Court's attention to the pages 32 to 65 of the observations of November 30, 2011.
In the often cited case of Ireland v. UK, the Court found that when tolerance

has been shown to exist at a higher level of the State, this fact alone would be a strong indication that the complainant has no possibility of obtaining redress through any national organ, including the courts, and that, therefore, the domestic remedies are not applicable.

In the same case, it was found that even if tolerance is observed only at the lower level, while there may be potentially the remedies to be exhausted, the Commission must have regard to the question whether or not the higher authorities of the State have themselves exercised their duty towards the individuals concerned to identify the practice and to prevent the occurrence or repetition of that act in question.
In Akdiva v. Turkey, this Court obligated the applicants to have normal recourse
to the remedies which are available and sufficient to afford redress in respect of the breaches alleged.
For a remedy to be available, it must exist at the time the application is lodged and must be directly accessible to individuals.
We argue that no remedy was available to the Georgian nationals at the time the present application was lodged.
Firstly, the Russian officials have effectively precluded Georgian nationals from exhausting domestic remedies.
In a short period of time, thousands of ethnic Georgians were singled out and expelled.

According to the Human Rights Watch, while many expelled may technically have had a judicial decision ordering their expulsion, the manner in which those decisions were reached, some in group trials, the lack of representation and capacity to mount a proper case against the expulsion, and the fact that the many were effectively denied the right to appeal, points to Russia's failure to comply with its ECHR obligations.

The witnesses who testified before the Court confirmed that they had short collective trials, they had not received decisions on expulsion, they were not represented by a counsel and or by interpreter to understand the essence of the proceedings.

They were not informed about the possibility of appeal, but were encouraged by police and judicial officials to leave the country as soon as possible, as there was a special order, brikas, demanding their expulsion.
It should be further observed that on 3 October 2006, all aerial, road, maritime, railway, postal, and financial links were suspended between the two states.

While there is no need to argue about the general ineffectiveness of the domestic remedies in the Russian Federation, the Georgian government strongly believes that due to the special circumstances prevailing at the material time, remedies, even those theoretically available in the Russian legislation, became futile.
The Court acknowledged in the Aktyvar case that the existence of special circumstances may absolve an applicant from the requirement of exhaustion of domestic remedies.

We suggest the Court to make realistic account of not only the existence of formal remedies in the legal system of the Russian Federation, but also the general legal and political context in which they operated, as well as the personal circumstances of Georgian nationals at that time.
Human Rights Watch describes the general and case-specific situation in the Respondent State at relevant time as follows.

Immediately after the escalation of Russian-Georgian political tension in late September 2006, Russian officials made repeated public statements singling out Georgians as illegal migrants, portraying them as criminals and calling for measures to be taken against them.

Russian television stations, the largest of which are owned and controlled by people close to the government, actively supported and justified the government singling out of Georgians through daily news programs and other programmings, and often quoted senior officials making strong anti-Georgian statements.
At the same time, Moscow police began to conduct widespread document inspections of ethnic Georgians.
To more efficiently locate Georgians, some police officers targeted locations where Georgians were likely to assemble.

The factual circumstances of the present case, as reflected in the witness statements, media, and NGO reports, as well as in the assessments of international organizations, viewed in the prism of the Court's well-developed case law, absolve the applicant from the requirements to exhaust domestic remedies.
Mr. President, Your Excellencies, with your permission, I would like to move to the
applicant's claims on merits of the case.

As Your Excellencies are well informed, the applicant government argues that the Russian Federation violated Articles 3, 5, 8, 13, 14, and 18 of the Convention, Articles 1 and 2 of Protocol 1, Article 4 of Protocol 4, and Article 1 of Protocol 7.
I will briefly explore both the law and the facts supporting applicant state's claims on violation of the said provisions of the Convention and the protocols thereto.
We maintain our detailed submissions on merits that are provided in our original application and in the observations submitted on November 30, 2011.
Your Excellencies, Respondent State has violated Article 3 of the Convention with respect to arrest, detention, and expulsion conditions of the Georgian nationals in the fall of 2006.
The detention conditions both in police isolators and in the detention centers for foreign nationals were appalling.

The witnesses who have testified to the Court have confirmed that the detention cells were extremely overcrowded, hygiene conditions were very poor, and they had no access to medical professionals, even when very much needed.

The detailed summary of witness statements in relation to detention conditions, as well as the means of expulsion of ethnic Georgians, is provided on pages 66 to 70 of Georgia's written observation of November 30, 2011.
In my presentation today, I will show why those witness statements shall be regarded as compelling.
For these purposes, I will kindly draw the Court's attention to the only report of the Council of Europe Committee Against Torture, referred as CPT, of the Russian Federation that is public.
Your Excellencies know that very few states refuse the publication of the CPT reports.
The Respondent State is one of those few.
Despite the requests made in the course of the witness hearings to disclose the CPT reports, the Respondent State has failed to share them with the Court.
However, the only public report that dates 2001 gives sufficient information about the detention conditions in the Russian Federation.
According to the CPT, the police isolators were not equipped with facilities suitable for overnight stays.
The cells seen by the delegation were totally unacceptable for extended periods of custody, dark, poorly ventilated, dirty, and usually devoid of any equipment except a bench.
Persons held overnight were not provided with mattresses or blankets.
Further, there was no provision for supplying detainees with food and drinking water, and access to a toilet was problematic.

The CPT describes the situation as equally alarming in the detention centers for foreign nationals in Moscow, where people were kept in overcrowded cells without access to basic amenities and the possibilities for contact with the outside world.
The annual Human Rights Report of the United States State Department, published in 2008, is instructive as it describes the detention conditions as harsh and frequently life-threatening.

Specifically in relation to ethnic Georgians in 2006, the special reporter of the UN General Assembly finds that the Georgian nationals were inter alia, deprived sufficient nutrition and medical aid while awaiting expulsion.

A Russian NGO memorial concurs with all the previous reports by saying that the detention centers for foreign nationals are not originally designed for long-term detention, but are reception centers, temporary detention, and even sobering up stations.

In 2006, Svetlana Ganushkina, a well-known Russian human rights activist, expressed her concern that the centers for temporary detention, centers of foreigners where foreigners face expulsion, are overfilled with meager food, cramped surroundings, lack of necessary sanitary conditions, and medical assistance, inaccessible legal help.
By international standards, Svetlana Ganushkina concludes, such conditions may be compared to the use of torture against detainees.
Georgian consul to the Russian Federation, Mr. Bataridze, who testified before
this court, stated that he visited various detention centers in various parts of the Russian Federation, and the conditions there were very harsh.
Cells were overcrowded, hygiene conditions were deplorable, it was cold and humid.
There were not enough beds and mattresses in the cells.
According to him, conditions were exceptionally difficult in the detention center of St. Petersburg.
This is a detention facility where Georgian national, Tengiz Togonidze, was detained.
The conditions there were so appalling that even the Federal Migration Service of the Russian Federation agreed that it should have been closed quickly.
Mr. Togonidze died before the deportation due to the unbearable detention
conditions and the absence of appropriate medical care.
Unfortunately, Mr. Togonidze is not the only Georgian who died in detention.
Two other Georgians shared the tragic fate, and the one suffered a stroke as a result of poor detention conditions.
The conditions were equally harsh in the buses that were used for transporting Georgians from the detention centers in different regions to Moscow airport for the deportation.
After days and sometimes weeks spent in inhuman conditions, the detainees had to stay in the buses without fresh air for hours.
They had to pay for basic services like using the toilet, smoking a cigarette, and even breathing the fresh air.
Georgian witnesses confirmed that they had to pay 300 rubles for toilet, though most of them had no money after the suffering they went through.
After days and sometimes weeks of detention and humiliation, Georgian nationals were deported by a cargo plane unsuitable for transporting people.

The witnesses told the court at the witness hearing that the wooden benches in the plane were not enough for the passengers, and they had either to sit on their small backs or to stand during three hours flight.
The toilet in the plane was moving around until they fixed it with the backs.
From the very moment of the arrest, Georgian nationals were humiliated by the officials of the Respondent State.
The witnesses recall stories that clearly show that Georgians were put in particularly bad conditions due to their origin.
Witness Irina Chokhely said to the court that she was told to drink the water from the toilet and leave the country because she was Georgian.
Georgians had no possibility to challenge the deplorable conditions of detention.

The court is aware from the judgment of Ananiyev versus Russian Federation that the Russian legal system does not dispose of an effective remedy that could be used to prevent the alleged violation or its continuation and provide the applicant with adequate and sufficient redress in connection with the complaints about inadequate conditions of detention.

According to the all above mentioned, the applicant strongly believes that the severe overcrowding in the cells, inadequacy of the sleeping arrangements, lack of sanitation and privacy, the fact that the detainees lived, slept and used the toilet in a single room, the incidences of deaths and serious illnesses among the detainees, as well as the conditions in the buses and the use of the cargo plane for the expulsion of Georgians as a whole is a clear indication that the Russian Federation fell short of its obligations under Article 3 of the Convention.

Moreover, due to the ethnically motivated ill-treatment and the absence of legal remedies against poor detention conditions, the applicant submits that there is a violation of Article 3 separately and in conjunction with Article 14 and 13 of the Convention.

Your Excellencies, the applicant states further contests that the Russian Federation breached Article 5, paragraph 1, due to arbitrary detention of ethnic Georgians and Article 5, paragraph 4, due to the denial of opportunity to challenge the legality of their arrest and detention.

The arrest of Georgians with a view to their expulsion took the form of mass operation, including spot checks in churches, markets and stores, and the spot checks in churches, markets and streets, as well as in homes and educational institutions and places of work through ethnic profiling.
Georgians were arrested and detained due to their ethnicity, rather than due to their immigration status.
Witness Mr. Toalavadze testified before the Court that they did not even look at
the documents.
They just knew I was Georgian right away.
We were told all the time, don't say anything, don't do anything, you are Georgians, don't ask why you are being deported to Georgia.
When you get back to Georgia, you can ask your president.
The witness statements on ethnically motivated detention and expulsion are confirmed by independent sources.
Human Rights Watch is particularly interesting in this regard.

The 2007 report, Single Out, says police targeted individuals whom they suspected were Georgian on the basis of their appearance, stopped them on the street in order to check the validity of their passports or other documents, and subsequently detained them, often irrespective of the legality of their documents.

Your Excellencies, I have shown earlier in my presentation dealing with administrative practice and the exhaustion of domestic remedies that there were no remedies available to ethnic Georgians to challenge the detention.
Courts that should have examined the legality of detention for expulsion just rubber-stamped the decisions.
Georgians became victims of collective trials, and they were discouraged to appeal the decisions as there were no prospects of success.
I will further elaborate on the manner the so-called trials were conducted when I move to the applicant's arguments on Article 4 of Protocol 4.

Based on the detailed information and evidence available in the case file, we respectfully request the Court to find that the arrest of Georgians was arbitrary, ethnically motivated, and discriminatory.
The detained Georgians had no opportunity to effectively challenge their detention.
Therefore, the Respondent's State shall be found in breach of Article 5, paragraphs 1 and 4 separately and in conjunction with Article 13 and 14 of the Convention.
Applicant's State claims that in the course of the arrest, detention, and expulsion of ethnic Georgians, the Respondent's State violated Article 8 of the Convention.

It is not challenged by the Respondent that the police sent requests to schools asking for the information about ethnic Georgian pupils and their parents, their home addresses, and other personal data.

According to Human Rights Watch, pupils at schools were questioned in order to establish their exact home address, which the police officers and migration authorities then visited and apprehended their parents.

The disclosure of information by schools and universities as to the background and address of pupils and students was not prescribed by the domestic law and, as a consequence, was a violation of Article 8.
Moreover, Article 8 is implicated in the cases of unlawful family separation.
At least on six occasions, parents were expelled while their minor children were left behind.
Therefore, the Court should find a violation of Article 8 of the Convention.

Applicants also submit that the arrest and detention of Georgians in public places, as well as the manner they were expelled from the Respondent's State, resulted in them being forced to abandon their property.
There was no opportunity to make any arrangements to look after the property that the Georgian citizens were obliged to leave behind.

In the wake of the massive operations against Georgian businesses and Georgian workers, many Georgians across Russia felt compelled to shut down their market stalls and businesses out of fear of being raided and expelled from the country.
More detailed facts on property-related claims are provided in our original application.
The accumulation of those facts support that the violation of Article 1 of Protocol 1 of the Convention took place.
It is an established fact that the police officers and migration authorities visited the schools and universities.
Georgian students at various universities were detained at lectures and in auditoriums, searched and taken to police stations without being charged in any concrete illegal activity.
We submit that the right to education of many Georgians was violated by the Respondent's State.

Furthermore, the applicant's state submits that the Respondent has collectively expelled ethnic Georgians from the territory of the Russian Federation and denied them their right to have the cases reviewed.
The detainees were collectively brought to a judge.
The so-called trials lasted for a few minutes without the possibility to have legal counsel and an interpreter.
Some of the detainees were not even formally brought to a judge.
Witness Mikhail Zurashvili told this court that the officers kept him and many other Georgians in buses for some time.
Then they were given the court's decisions without entering the court building, let alone seeing a judge personally.
They were forced to sign the decision without having the possibility to read it.

The detained Georgians were discouraged by the police, the officers in the detention centers, and even by the judges not to appeal the decisions by saying inter alia that they had to be happy for still being alive.
Another witness, Koba Gabunia, whose court hearing lasted no more than five minutes, was told by a judge that there was no point in appealing since there was an order from the above.
Tengiz Milashvili said to the court, when we got to the place, they said, sign here.
How could I read it?
They were saying, faster, faster.
They did not give us the time to read them.
And when we left the building, they told us that it was a court.
I did not know it was a court.
I mean, there was some young lady there, and that was it.
Your Excellencies, I can go with a long list of witness statements, confirming the absence of any meaningful court hearing of the cases.
Though due to the time constraints, I would kindly refer to pages 69 and 70 of our written observations of November 30, 2011, where the relevant summaries of witness statements are provided.

Though I will once again allow myself to cite the Human Rights Watch, which says, while many expelled Georgians may technically have had a judicial decision ordering the expulsion, the manner in which those decisions were reached, some in-group trials, the lack of representation and capacity to mount a proper case against the expulsion, and the fact that many were effectively denied the right to appeal, points to Russia's failure to comply with its international obligations.

To conclude, it is apparent that the victims were not afforded a procedure with sufficient guarantees that demonstrated that the personal circumstances of each of them had been taken into consideration to any extent.
The witnesses have demonstrated that the courts were not willing to listen to their submissions as to why they should not have been expelled.
Judges used the same form to order the expulsion, inserting only their names and the dates, without dealing with any factual circumstances of the individual cases.
Some of the victims did not even have an opportunity to appear before the court, let alone appeal the court decision on expulsion.

The action taken by the Russian authorities constitutes a collective measure against a group of Georgian nationals, and, as a consequence, their expulsion should be regarded as a violation of Article 4, of Protocol 4, separately and in conjunction with Article 13 and 14 of the Convention.
Your Excellencies, this Court reiterates in a number of cases, including in a more recent Bolat v. Russia, and the applicant state fully shares that the high-contracting
parties have a discretionary power to decide whether to expel an eligible person or to expel an alien present in their territory.
But this power must be exercised in such a way as not to infringe the rights under the Convention of the person concerned.

First and foremost, the applicant state submits that the Article 1 of Protocol 7 applies to the present case, and the Respondent's frequently invoked argument that the status of expelled Georgians is misleading.
It is true that some of those expelled did not technically meet the complex and often confusing requirements of the Russian migration legislation.
However, there is strong evidence supporting that many of those expelled were legally residing in the country.
Therefore, Article 1 of Protocol 7 is of relevance in the present case.

According to the monitoring committee of the Council of Europe Parliamentary Assembly, the issue of the great number of Georgians living in Russia illegally is linked to a structural problem of Russia's immigration policies.
In 2002, due to the adoption of the new law and maintaining the deficient administrative system, people who had been living in Russia for years suddenly became illegal migrants.
The PACE concludes that the time anti-Georgian campaign began in October, repressive mechanisms against foreign citizens had already been created in Russian legislation.

The UN Special Rapporteur on Contemporary Forms of Racism, Racial Discrimination, Xenophobia, and Related Intolerance, qualifies the situation as institutionalized discrimination provided by the legislation.

The UN Committee Against Torture recommended the Russian Federation in 2006 to clarify the violations of immigration rules, which may result in administrative expulsion and establish clear procedures to ensure they are implemented fairly.
Due to the well-recognized structural deficiencies of the migration system in the respondent state, the Georgian nationals were left without the safeguards of Article 1 of Protocol 7.
They were expelled without proper determination of the status by the domestic courts.
Many Georgians were expelled even before the appeal hearings were conducted.
There are numerous cases of the expulsion, them being stripped of their citizenship.
The factor of ethnic origin is a late motive of the present case, and it is supported both by the witness statements that I have referred to above, as well as by independent sources.
Therefore, we submit to the Court that there is a violation of Article 1 of Protocol 7 separately and in conjunction with Article 13 and 14 of the Convention.
Last but not least, I would like to elaborate on the applicability and violation of Article 18 of the Convention in the present case.
Your Excellencies, I deliberately kept the question of Article 18 at the end of my presentation, after all relevant facts and law are submitted.
It is clear that the respondent state has used its machinery in bad faith for the political retaliation against the government of Georgia.

The anti-Georgian rhetoric that reached its climax in the Russian political establishment after the arrest of four Russian spies in Georgia is a clear manifestation of the hidden agenda behind the mass expulsion of Georgians from the respondent state.
The statements made by high-ranking Russian officials varied from no need for Georgians in Russia to threatening with the use of military force.
These political statements were easily translated into the official orders and later into the implementing circulars and, most importantly, into the actions.

After the ethnic profiling and arrest in streets, marketplaces, places of work and residence, Georgians were deliberately sent to detention centers even when they were ready to leave the country voluntarily.
Miss Irina Chokheli told the courts that she was not allowed to leave the country.
I was told, no, you will be sent to Georgia as a prisoner, as a detainee.
It was a deliberate policy of putting Georgian nationals in grave suffering and thus retaliating against the government of Georgia.
Human Rights Watch unequivocally concluded in 2007 that the expulsion of Georgians in 2006 was an example of foreign policy tactics of Russia, not related to the migration control.
Your Excellencies, there has been hardly more clear case of breach of Article 18 in the rich case law of this court.
Therefore, we strongly believe that this court should find the breach of Article 18 in conjunction with Article 5, paragraph 1 of the convention.
Your Excellencies, with your permission, I will now conclude with the applicant state's prayers for relief.

The government of Georgia respectfully asks the honorable court to examine the case on merits to find violation of Article 3, 5, 8, 13, 14, and 18 of the convention, Article 1 and 2 of Protocol 1, Article 4 of Protocol 4, and Article 1 of Protocol 7.

To award just satisfaction under Article 41, namely compensation, reparation, restitution in integrum, cost, expenses, and further and other relief to be specified for all the pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage suffered or incurred by the injured parties as a result of the violations and the pursuit of these proceedings.
Mr. President, Your Excellencies, let me finish here and
thank you for your attention.
Thank you very much, Ms. Burjaliani.
Then I give the floor to Mr. Matyushkin for the government of the Russian Federation.
Mr. Matyushkin, please.
Human Rights Watch, - , , , , .
Human Rights Watch , .
Human Rights Watch .
Thank you very much, Mr Matyushkin.
We have then come to the end of the first round of pleadings, and I would like to ask if any of the judges wish to put questions to either of the parties.
Judge Kovler.
Thank you, Mr. President.
I have two questions to both parties.
The first question to the Georgian representative.
In the relevant time, Georgia was a member of the Community of Independent States.
There are some agreements regulating migration problems between these states.
For example, the agreement of 6 March 1998 on the prevention of illegal migration.
Also another agreement concerning cooperation of states in the field of labor migration and social protection of labor immigrants of 1994.
Did Georgia participate in these agreements?
This is my question.
The second question, Mr. President, with your permission, comes to the representative of
Russian Federation.
I know that the Federal Immigration Service of Russian Federation has its representatives in many countries.
I would like to know, did this service establish such representatives in Georgia in the relevant time besides the consular services?
Thank you.
Thank you very much, Judge De Gaetano.

I would like to hear the parties additional views on article 38 of the convention and in particular on the circumstances, if any, when a state party to the convention can raise the plea of, say, state secret or official secret or national security in opposition to that article.

How, if at all, can, for instance, national security, which admittedly can be a genuine and legitimate concern, be reconciled with a state party's undertaking under article 1 of the convention to secure to all persons within its jurisdiction the substantive rights and freedoms mentioned in the convention, in the event, of course, of a person instituting proceedings, either domestically or in Strasbourg, against that state?
Thank you.
Thank you very much. Are there any further questions which you wish to put?
Yes, please, judge Kalaydjieva.
Thank you, President.
In fact, I have one question to the applicant government and one to the respondent government.
The applicant government refers to an administrative practice.
Would you please specify whether this administrative practice is, in your view, restricted to Georgians for a relevant period and what period?
When did it start and when did it finish?
Or is it an administrative practice that continues after this period that is in the application?
And as to what moment?

My question to the respondent government relates to their submissions that the government of the Federation of Russia was exercising its authority to ensure a proper migration policy in the relevant period.

Are you able to offer statistical data as to the percentage of Georgian nationals or ethnic Georgians that left the Federation in the period concerned in the application in previous and subsequent periods so that one may understand whether this percentage was higher or this number was higher for the relevant period as compared to earlier and subsequent ones?
Would you also be able to provide information on these numbers in regard of other nationalities or aliens?
Thank you.
Thank you very much.
Are there any other questions?
That doesn't seem to be the case.
So we will adjourn now until 11.15.
La Cour!
Please be seated.
The hearing is resumed. I'll give the floor to Miss Burjaliani, please.
Thank you, Mr. President.
First, I will answer to the questions posed by the honorable judges.
And then I will comment and reply to some of the issues and arguments raised by the respondent states in its submissions.
First question from Judge Kovler.
I confirmed that the two agreements mentioned by you were not ratified by the Georgian parliament, so they have never been binding for Georgia.
Next question was about the application of Article 38 and the relation between Article 38 with the interest of a state to protect its national security.

Our understanding of Article 38 is based on the language of this provision itself, which says, among other things, that the high contracting parties concerned shall furnish all necessary facilities to the court.
This is what is meant.
The language of the article is very precise and strong.
There is no restriction or possibility of restriction provided in the text itself.

This is exactly how this Court has interpreted Article 38 and the obligations provided by this article in the previous case law, by highlighting that there is an unequivocal obligation, very clear obligation of the parties to the disputes to provide the court with all necessary information requested by the court that are necessary for the proper administration of justice.

But at the same time, we have seen in a number of cases decided by this Court that this Court is equipped with all necessary tools to protect the confidential or secret information without prejudice to the national interest or national security interests of the state.
Therefore, the applicant state's reading of the Article 38 is straightforward.
The parties to these proceedings are obliged to provide all necessary information to the court without any limitation.
Next question was about the time frame of administrative practice and the application in general.
Your Excellencies, we limit our application to a certain period of time, which is from the late September 2006 to January 2007.
Accordingly, the administrative practice challenged in Georgia's application refers to those facts that occurred during this period of time.
So it is late September 2006 to January 2007.

With your permission, I will refrain to make any general comment about the administrative practice type violation of or treatment of Georgians in the respondent state afterwards, because the situation after January 2007 is not really challenged in our application.
I believe these are the answers from the applicant state to the questions raised by the judges.
I will use the time that I have at disposal to respond to some of the issues raised by the judges.
I will also touch on the issues raised by the respondent state.
First of all, I will touch the issue of statistics, which seems to be an important question based on today's hearing.
Your Excellencies, I would kindly draw your attention to the fact that the respondent state bases its argument on the statistical information provided to the court.
We know, the court knows, that this statistical information is a collection of monthly statistics.
Respondent states explained to us that they don't collect the monthly statistics, but they have biannual statistics.
Biannual statistics, even if it is 100% accurate, does not show a clear picture of the situation.
Applicant states contest the reliability of the statistics due to the reason I have just mentioned.
The fact is that we challenge that the number of Georgians deported from the Russian Federation in September, October, and November 2006 have increased around eight times.
This is a time period where a particular important increase of number of deportees is visible.
It's visible from the information that the Minister of Internal Affairs, Border Police of Georgia collected.
Again, I will allow myself to reiterate that even our statistics is not 100%, but it is very moderate.
It is very true because it only registers those individuals who came to Georgia directly from the Russian Federation via air transport or land transport by their own means or by any possible means.
Therefore, we suggest that the statistics provided by the applicant state shall be viewed as reliable.
At the same time, I would like to reiterate that the respondent states do have an obligation to have adequate statistics of those deportees deported from the Russian Federation.
Unfortunately, the information that we have seen is of very little relevance for the present case.

Next point that I would like to once again highlight, which is extremely important in order to clarify Georgia's position in the present case, is that we do believe that each and every state has its sovereign right to regulate migration, and we don't challenge this sovereign right.
What we say in the present case is that the policy implemented and the actions implemented by the respondent state in the time contested in our application was not related to the migration control.
In fact, it was abuse of migration legislation of the respondent state in violation of its international obligations.
We share the case law.
We fully agree with the case law of this honorable court that the migration control also is reserved as a sovereign right to the state.
The states are obliged to exercise this sovereignty in full compliance with its international obligations, including its obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights.
I would like also to refer to the issue of appeal and exhaustion of domestic remedies.
Your Excellencies, I would like to remind you that most of the Georgians were expelled very soon, almost immediately after the expulsion decisions were made by the court.
Therefore, the 10-day time limit for the appeal really lost its importance in the cases of Georgians.

Exactly the Russian legislation provides 10 days for appeal, but in the cases of Georgian nationals, those 10-day period were not really respected and insured by the state authorities because they were expelled before the expiration of the 10-day time limit.
The second issue is that many Georgians were forced to sign this so-called waiver of appeal.

I have outlined in my presentation, and there is also plenty of evidence available in the case files, that shows that ethnic Georgians, Georgian nationals, did not really know what they were signing for different reasons.
First of all, they were forced to sign the documents and forced not to read what they were supposed to sign.
Second, they had no access to a lawyer.
They did not have an interpreter.

And you have seen during the witness hearings as well that most of these people did not have experience of dealing with court hearings or dealing with complex legal issues, and they could not really understand the essence of the proceedings.

Another important point that should be taken into consideration while discussing the issue of appeal and exhaustion of domestic remedies is that Georgians were expressly encouraged by the authorities, including by the judges, not to file the appeal because there was a brikas, a special order that all the Georgians were obliged to leave the country as soon as possible.
The same rhetoric was used in conversation with the Georgian consul, Mr. Bataridze,
who was advised by officers in the detention centers that he should take care of detained Georgians and should ensure their transportation to Georgia as soon as possible.

In addition, Georgians were kept in inhuman detention conditions before they were brought to courtrooms, and they had in mind that in case of appeal, they had to go back to the extremely difficult detention conditions that amounted to inhuman treatment.

Therefore, we believe that exactly there was special circumstance prevailing at a material time, and Georgian nationals did not have opportunity to have access to efficient and effective domestic remedies.

I would like also to briefly mention one point and to highlight that my distinguished colleague from the Russian Federation mentioned a number of times the issue of manifestly ill-founded nature of the present application.

Our understanding is that this court in its admissibility decision of June 30, 2009 has already established that the application is not manifestly ill-founded, and today we are examining the administrative practice and exhaustion of domestic remedies as long as it is important and related to the allegations on merits.
Thank you very much for your attention.
Thank you very much, Mrs. Burjaliani. Then I give the floor to Mr. Matyushkin, please.
Thank you very much, Mr. Matyushkin.
Mr. Matyushkin, I wonder if I may put one further question to you.
You've talked about the two seculars being covered by state secrecy, and you've told us that there were at least two classifications, secret and confidential.
Can you tell us whether these two documents were covered by a classification of secret or confidential?
Thank you very much, Mr. Matyushkin.
We have now then come to the end of the hearing.
I would like to thank the parties for their interventions and their answers to the court's questions.
The court will now deliberate on the merits.
The judgment will be delivered later, and the parties will be informed of the date of delivery.
I declare closed the hearing in the case of Georgia against Russia.
